meanings.def: dislike of or opposition to a plan, an idea, etc.; the act of refusing to obey
examples: As with all new ideas it met with resistance.
resistance to somebody/something There has been a lot of resistance to this new law.
Resistance to change has nearly destroyed the industry.
There was fierce resistance to the new laws.
They mounted stiff resistance to the proposal.

meanings.def: the act of using force to oppose somebody/something
examples: There were a number of episodes of armed resistance during the early years of occupation.
The defenders put up a strong resistance.
resistance to somebody/something The demonstrators offered little or no resistance to the police.
The attacks did not take place without resistance.
The advancing army met with little resistance.

meanings.def: the power not to be affected by something
examples: AIDS lowers the body's resistance to infection.
Many viruses develop resistance to drugs.
These varieties produce a lot of fruit and have excellent disease resistance.
You need to build up your resistance to colds.

meanings.def: a force that stops something moving or makes it move more slowly
examples: wind/air resistance (= in the design of planes or cars)

meanings.def: the opposition of a substance or device to the flow of an electrical current
a secret organization that resists the authorities, especially in a country that an enemy has control of
(to choose, etc.) the easiest way of doing something

idioms.idiom: (choose, follow, take, etc.) the line/path of least resistance
idioms.def: (to choose, etc.) the easiest way of doing something

related: (choose, follow, take, etc.) the line/path of least resistance
